content.title: Are you keeping the Ayyame Beez fasts?
content.subtitle: Suhoor tonight in Bangladesh
content.body:
In Bangladesh, the Ayyame Beez (white days) voluntary fasts for the current month of Sha'ban should be observed on the following days:

üóìÔ∏è Dates: February 2, 3 & 4 (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday)

üçõ Suhoor: Tonight, Sunday, February 1st

Did you know? If you keep these 3 fasts each month, Almighty Allah will give you the reward of fasting the entire month! Because the reward for every good deed is multiplied up to 10 times. (3 days x 10 times = reward of 30 days!)

ü§≤ May Allah grant us the ability to perform these voluntary acts of worship regularly. Fasting is very easy in winter. Ramadan is coming soon. Let's prepare ourselves for Ramadan.

What to Do and Avoid on Laylatul Nisf min Sha'ban or Shab-e-Barat:

There are various extremist views about Shab-e-Barat in society. Some completely deny it, while others engage in innovation (bid'ah). Here's an overview of the correct information in light of hadith and Sunnah:

Date: Shab-e-Barat in 2026 falls on the night following Tuesday, February 3rd.

‚ûú Significance: In hadith, it is called 'Laylatul Nisf min Sha'ban' or the middle night of Sha'ban. According to authentic hadith, on this night Allah forgives everyone except polytheists and the envious.

‚ûú Not the Night of Destiny: The 'blessed night' in Surah Dukhan is actually Laylatul Qadr (in Ramadan), not Shab-e-Barat. This is essentially the 'Night of Forgiveness.'

‚ûú Correct Actions: Individually performing voluntary prayers, repentance, long prostrations, and seeking forgiveness. Collective worship or elaborate Milad gatherings in mosques are not supported by the Sunnah.

‚ûú Next Day's Fast: Fasting on the 15th of Sha'ban is recommended as part of Ayyame Beez. Keeping one fast specifically for Shab-e-Barat is also permissible (based on weak hadith and virtuous deeds).

‚ûú Innovations to Avoid: Distributing halwa-roti (sweet bread), fireworks, lighting candles on graves, taking a bath with special intention for Shab-e-Barat, or praying in a specific prescribed manner‚Äînone of these have any basis in Islam.

‚úÖ Summary: Avoiding extremes and adopting moderation is true Islam. The main goal of this night is to seek Allah's forgiveness by being free from shirk (polytheism) and envy.

Share this with your acquaintances. If someone finds the right path through you, you will also share in their reward, Insha'Allah.
